Title: Simulation of Transport between the Adriatic Sea and the Danube (STRADA)

The STRADA project proposes the development of a dynamic computer-based simulation system to reconstruct and analyze the ancient transport network between the Adriatic Sea and the Danube River during the Roman Empire. This innovative approach will enable researchers to study the spatial and temporal interconnectivity between Roman Italy and the Danube frontier, and investigate how environmental factors influenced the transport system. By integrating experimental data, historical research, and technological advancements, STRADA will introduce dynamic simulations into historical research, providing new insights into the economic cohesion of the Roman Empire.

The simulation system will feature a modular design, allowing for sustainable use and future extension. It will incorporate local fine-grained topography, historical weather data, and various means of transport with different loads, as well as factors such as fatigue, rests, and loading times. The project will focus on reconstructing ancient land and water routes, experimentally determining the performance of different transport modes under changing environmental conditions, and developing a time-related simulation system.

By simulating realistic transport times and scenarios, STRADA will contribute significantly to our understanding of the Roman Empire's economic dynamics and the interconnectedness of its territories. The project's results will have far-reaching implications for the fields of archaeology, history, and environmental studies, and will provide a new framework for analyzing ancient transport systems.
